div.head: Deliramenta Catarrhi: OR, THE INCONGRUITIES, IMPOSSIBILITIES, and ABSURDITIES Couched under the Vulgar Opinion of DEFLUXIONS.
div.p: The Author, That great Philoopher, by Fire, Joh. Bapt. an Helmont, &c.
The Tranlator and Paraphrat Dr. CHARLETON, Phyician to the late KING.
LONDON, Printed by E. G. for William Lee at the igne of the Turks-head in Fleet-treet. 1650.

div.head: The Tranlator to the Judicious and (therefore) unprejudicate Reader.
div.p:
SO malevolent, evere, and uncharitable have the Cenures of many (yet uch onely, I conceive, whoe parcel-literature, and incapacity of the more olid and weighty Notions of Philoophy, delivered in mot proper and ignificant language, have depraved their Appetite of Knowledge, and made them fit to diget nothing, but crude Sallads gathered in the Poets Elizium, and oft Romances, oyled with the effeminate Extracts of the Stage, and piced with ome new French-Englih idioms) been of my precedent exercie; that the World might expect from me rather a Vindication of that, then the Publication of a econd, of the ame kind. But as I ever levelled my endeavors at a far nobler end, then the
nothing of vulgar Applaus: o alo have I declared the temper of my Genius to be too Stoical, to feel the weak aaults of that cowardly Pygmie, detraction; whom hanomly to overcome, is to corne. For common obervation will jutifie, that no man ever entered the lits with that ignorant Bug-bear, but lot much by the encounter: his judgement inevitably receiving uch VVounds, as the reputation of his Courage could never cure, or compenate.

Nor hall I at all recede from this Maxime, though I here adventure to profee, that next to the dicharge of that duty, which, as a Scholer, I owe unto the Publique, in the Explanation, Improvement, and Communication of obcure Truths; the mot forcible motive, that incited me to betow a few recreative houres on the Tranlation, and marginal Paraphrae of this piece of Helmont, was to have an opportunity of letting thee Semi-criticks know: that though they have privately accued, yet would it have tood more with their Honour publickly to have convicted me of uch improprieties of expreion, or unnatural perverions of my Authors ene, as might make me alter any thing of moment in the former, or change my tile in the preent dicoure.

For though I am ufficiently concious to my elf of more defects, and greater unevennee of my Pen, then the acutet of my Calumniators can dicover; and do account it more noble to detect my own, then others Frailties: yet I dare appeal to the ober Deciion of any, whoe Studies hold any proportion with the Subject, (and uch onely can I allow for competent Judges) whether the fine and myterious nature of many things, treated of in that dicoure, might not have uffered a groe Eclipe, if dret in a meer-Englih veil? Whether it be a Crime in me to trace the footteps of thoe Worthies, who have infinitely botb enriched and ennobled our Language, by admitting and naturalizing thouands of forraigne Words, providently brought home from the Greek, Roman, Italian, and French Oratories; which, though in the untraveld ears of our Fathers they would have ounded as harh, as St. Pauls
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Ineffabilia verba. 2. Cor. 12. c. ver. 4.; yet have a few years made o familiar unto us, that now even Children peak much of Latine, before they can well read a word of Englih? And to draw in to the Center of the candal, whether I have merited the Epithite of < in non-Latin alphabet >
Qui venutatem verborum, non enuum acumen inectatur. of one that praefers
the noveltie, or affected elegance of the Phrae, to the nerves and importance of the ene; meerly becaue I rendered ome Phyical Notions in terms mot amply and adequately exhibiting their qualities; and thoe no other, but uch as are mot frequent in the Schools: and attempted to paint the beauty and life of Helmonts pruce Conceptions, in Colours mot trong and natural; though borrowed from the more praecie, ditinctive, and emphatical Tinctures of forreigne Artits?

I can not but applaud the Spirit, and happy Phanie of this Tetratick,
Legiti notros? riiti, Romule, libros? Cap. Hofmannus in praefatione ua ad lib. de Generat. Homin. Â¶
Ut vidi, ut rii, Romule Dive, tuos.
Quae Caua effectus paris in tam dipare caua?
Riiti ingenium tute, ego tultitiam.
And when any of the tribe of Zoilus hall hew us omething of their own, I may perchance be furnihed with an opportunity of Applying them.

But let I fall upon a Parergie, and looly deviate into that initer path, which my reolutions abhor; I return directly to my duty, which is to give the impartial Reader the Reaon, which perwaded me to exhibite my Explanation
of Helmonts unfrequent, and new coyned, or new-applied Termes of Art, in Latine. In a word, I conceived that the Quality of the Subject, intimated by each of thoe paradoxical Appellatives, being uch as falls under the comprehenion of none, but the leading part of learning, and chiefly thoe, who have more then looked into the myterious Temple of Aeculapius, did necearily require it: and that no Englih, how plain oever, could have driven their ample meaning into thoe skulls, which are o thick, as not to admit it in Latine.

As concerning the Verity of thee Paradoxes, inpered upon the enuing Treatie, though I have formerly declared my Averation to attempt any Commentary on, or deciive Aertion of any of his Innovations; in regard I ever found his reaon tronger at Demolihing the Doctrines of the Antient Pillars of our Art, then Erecting a more ubtantial and durable Structure of his own, his Witt more acute and active at Contradiction, then his judgement profound and authentick at Probation: yet hall I uurp the liberty to ay, that many of the Grounds of his quarrell againt the Schools, in this particular of Catarrhs,
are ufficiently jutifiable; and that if any member in the whole body of Phyick needs to have its errors purged, tupidity corrected, ditortions rectified, and leannee reformed, doubtlee this Capitall one of Defluxions may chiefly deerve the indutry of the preent, and gratefull improvement of the future Age. Nor hould I have onely aid it, had not my expectation, that ome more judicious and elegant hand will hortly et about that o neceary, charitable, and honourable task, whipered me, that this difficult, and (therefore) infinitely deiderable piece of knowledge, would unavoydably have uffered irreparable detriment, diparagement, and obcurity from the Contagion of my unequall undertaking. And I am bold to promie, that if any ober mind, imbued with that uefull Leon of Aritotle, Metaphyicorum lib. 3. cap. 1. & de Coelo lib. 1. cap. 10.
< in non-Latin alphabet > , hall come to the dipute, denudate of all interet, and purged from all the dreggs of Adhaerence to either ide; he hall oon be convicted, that in all that long flux of time betwixt the daies of Hippocrates and us, no one (at leat that ever came to our view) among the numerous warm of
Pathologits Writers on the Dieaes and Symptoms incident to the body of man., hath dicoured of the nature and caues of uch Dieaes as are in vulgar practice confidently referred unto the Ditillation of Rheums from the head upon parts of inferior ituation, with uch cleare and uncontroulable reaons, as not to have left very large gapps, for the eaie illation of thee cruples and objections raied by Helmont againt them. In brief; whoever hall o far contribute towards the advance of his own knowledge, as to receive the Arguments here oppoed to the traditional Theory of Catarrhs, with that equal jutice of improving them to that height, with which they are offered; will, I doubt not, afford us his concurrent vote: that the chiefe impediment to their prevailing upon the beliefe of many dienters, will be their Novelty. For hardly doe we part with thoe Doctrines, which intilled into our tender and un wary yeers, have grown up together with our undertandings, and hold our credulities enlaved to an implicite conformity, by the tyrannous title of Praecription. A deplorable remora to the timely exantlation of Truth, long ince dicovered and complained of by the grave and yet mot acute
Stagirite, in thee words: Metaphyic. lib. 2. cap. 3.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . Quemadmodum enim conuevimus, ita judicamus dici debere, & quae praeter haec non apparent imilia; ed quia non conuevimus, ignotiora & magis peregrina. Conueta enim notiora unt. I hall here o far exercie your Candor and Patience, as to tolerate a hort Digreion (though pertinent and material) concerning this Cardinal caue of < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Indocibility. The Decription of this vice of the minde, ince mot ample and elegant, I hall borrow from that Noble Enquirer into Truth, Mr. Hobbs, in his inetimable manual of Human Nature.
If the minds of men (ays he) were all of white Paper, they would, for the mot, be equally dipoed to acknowledge whatoever hould be in the right method, and right ratiocination, delivered unto them: but when men have once acquieced in untrue opinions, and regitred them as authenticall methods in their minds; it is no lee impoible to peak intelligibly to uch men, then to write legibly upon a peece of Paper already cribled over. The immediate
caue therefore of Indocibility, is Prejudice; and of prejudice, fale opinion of our own knowledge. The Naturall Reaon of it I hall adventure to deduce from the lender stock of my own Philoophy. We judge of the truth or falhood not onely of things ubject to the apprehenion of ence, but alo of Philoophicall and Religious opinions, as we have been accutomed from the minority of our ndertandings: and although many times we are greatly deluded, yet cannot the arm of the tronget reaon bend us from our accutomed judgement. The ground of this is, that not onely the Cur olitae opiniones placeant: inolitae, eti firmioribus rationibus bus innixae, dipliceant. Images, or bare Ideas (I mean not thoe intentionall pecies, o much talked of in common Philoophy, for I believe I could prove that there are no uch in Nature) of thoe things have an exitence in the brain; but certaine Notes or marks of Rejection or Approbation are alo uperadded unto them, and deeply impreed upon the brain. Thee Images therefore being again offered unto the mind, we perceive not only the things themelves; but at the ame intant, even without any haeitancy or accurate examination, yea though mot convincing
and firme arguments are ometimes brought to the contrary, with great violence, we approve or reject them according to the conformity or diproportion of thoe Notes formerly regitred. The remove of which obtruction hall be the contant buinee not onely of my tudies, but alo of my earnet prayer.

Quae in Schola & Cathedra aliquando praeter tationem, plerumque ad acuenda ingenia juvenrutis, in theoria proponuntur, unt toleranda: quae vero in praxi in perniciem aegrorum praecribuntur, potius execranda & damnanda, quam admittenda ee, exitimo.

q.l: Quid verum, atque decens curo, & rogo, & omn is in hoc um.
Condo, & compono quae mox depromere poim.
Ac ne forte roges, quo me duce, quo lare tuter?
Nullius addictus jurare in verba magitri,
Quo me cunque rapit tempet as, deferor hopes.
Nunc agilis fio, & meror civilibus undis,
Nunc in Aritippi furtim praecepta relabor:
Et mihi res, non me rebus ubjungere conor.

div.head: The Errors of Phyicians Concerning DEFLVXIONS.
The Summary.
div.p:
1. WHo is the Lord paramont of Dieaes and Nature, 2. Some uppoitions, by way of premies. 3. The concluion. 4. Proved from experiments. 5. The explication of the Poition. 6. The Lungs the part which firt dyes. 7. Why the Author deerted the Schools. 8. The forerunner of mieries to old men. 9. Purging medicaments, why detructive to old men. 10. The tetimonies that Phyicians give of their own ignorance, Fatall: becaue too late. 11. That Axiome of Phyicians deumed from the ue of things beneficiall and hurtfull, worthy their bluhes. 12. Errors of Phyicians. 13. The ground of Paracelus his incontancy. 14. The Generalogy of a Catarrh, or Rheume, like an old wives fable. 15. Dieaes imputed to Catarrhs. 16. How great calamity arifeth to mankinde from thence. 17. By what means they make the ick their perpetuall laves. 18. The ordinary ubteruge of the Schools. 19. Thirteen Poitions. 20 Nineteen Concluions emergent from thoe Poitions. 21. By a ufficient enumeration of Parts. 22. A Dilemma. 23. Some Aburdities. 24. Ignorance in the Schools, the ole Mother
of Catarrhs. 25 The ame Ignorance, the fountain of Aburdities in their method of Cure. 26. Shame, the Caue of the Schools intability, 27. A deniail of principles granted in the Schools 28. Whence heat is de â¢ ived to the Liver. 29, The proof from unucceefull remedies. 30. the Tooth-ach examined. 31. The digetion of the Tooth and Nails, different from the Digetion of all other parts. 32. A Catarrh upon the inward parts, demontrated impoible, 33. The Poe, or Cold in the head, decribed. 34. Aburdities dependent on the opinion of a Catarrh falling upon the tomack. 35. An enquiry concerning the dropping of Rheume upon the Lungs. 36. What ditills from the <> , in the beginning of a Cold, and what in the continuance. 37. An Argument ab im â¢â¢ i i â¢
againt the Caue of the Cough, delivered by the Schools. 38. The originall of the matter cauing affections of the Lungs, declared. 39 The vanity and infertility of remedies, from want of knowledge. 40. The decoctions of China, Zarza, &c. neither dry up excrementitious humors, nor prevent their generation. 41. Some Aburdities growing upon this root. 42. What s to be oberved in Affections of the Lungs, 43. The doctrine of the Schools, concerning the motion of the Lungs, fale. 44. The ue of he Lungs, not yet knowne to the Schools. 45. 21. Peremtory reaons againt the vulgar opinion of the ue of the Lungs. 46. The error of the Schools, concerning the ue of the Midrife, confirmed by 8. Arguments 47. 7. Concluions enuing thereon. 48. Why the remedies of Phyicians are inefficacious and barren. 49 That the means vulgarly ued for the prevention and retraint of Catarrhs, are meer fopperies, and dreams worthy onely the heads of old women. 50. Galen wholly ridiculous in his Books of the conervation of health. 51. The Ignorance of the Schools, right worthy our pitty and tears. 52 The diection of a living Dog, hath deceived the Schools. 53. A new Error, concerning Lohochs, or Lambativ medicaments. 54. They depend on the uppoition of a Fality. 55. Some probations. 56. Whence the deluion of Catarrhs was firt introduced. 57. The refutation of an unreaonable and wild peruaion. 58 What that is, which impoeth upon our ene, under the deluive diguie of a Detillation. 59. What the econd and ucceeding matter. 60. Mens ignorance of the Latex, or fountain o â¢ erous humors, hath been the bais to the opinion of Catarrhs. 61. Preoccupation. 62. The torture of night. 63. The incontancy of Paracelus.
64. Thoe liquid parts, which are not yet made communicants of vitality in our bodies, hold no correpondence with the tarrs. 65. The marrow not accountable amongt the liquid parts of the body. Â¶

SEaonable it is for us, now to declare, that the large Catalogue of Dieaes, imputed to a detillation of Rheume, from the head even to the extremity of the toes, without any obtacle impeding the decent, is an old wives fable, invented by the common adverary of mankind, on purpoe, let the Caues of Dieaes being known, their Remedies might at the ame time be revealed. However it may be, yet at let is it hence manifeted, that the Schooles are, even to this very day, educed by the errors of the Gentiles, in the point of the Generation of Rheume, its defluction, manner, way, matter, means, places, and organs; as alo of its Revulion and Remedies. For fale and aburd mut that upertructure be, which is founded on an aburd and impoible Principle. For which reaon, the vain and ridiculous hope, which is erected upon Cauteries and Fontanels, is in like manner taggered and ruined: as I hall, in convenient place, demontrate.

Nature herelfe is the ole Aeculapius of dieaes: and the Phyician no more but her Adjutant; according to that 1. worthy Maxime of Hippocrates. But the ene of that relates onely to uch dieaes, which nature, by her own ingle power, uually cureth. But when he hath been o fataly foyled, that he cannot by her own trength arie again to maintain the conflict; the Phyician, elected by the immene benignity of the Almighty Lord of Nature, and in whoe balance all dieaes carry the ame weight, (i. e.) are equaly curable (uch is he, who hath, among a multitude
of others of the ame order, obtained ome one niveral Medicine) remains no longer her ervant: but is become her Interpreter, Rector and very potent Lord. Let the name of my Lord Jeu be exalted to eternity, who ever vouchafeth his munificence to Little ones, abjected in their own humility! For the Nature of a ick man being the chiefe receiver of Morbifick impreions, and the enitive mover towards the contrary; the Patient mut, then at leat, when the dieaes entertained become prevalent, yield to their conquering word, or at bet, in the future, live a Calamitous death, unlee he hall be relieved and retored to his primitive integrity, by the auxiliary hand of the Phyician. Yet is it not in the lot of every Phyician, to arrive at Corinth, to acend to that excellent knowledge: but his onely, who hath the happy qualifications of a Vocation, Election, Exercitation, and Commiion. For in the lee accomplihed dayes of Hippocrates, the trancendent virtues of Catholique medicines remained in the darknee of undicovery (and in truth, even in our brighter dayes, they continue but jejune, and ecliped with prejudice and deriion, amongt vulgar Phyicians) upon which conideration, he is deervedly to be excued, in that he conceived the whole buinee of the conquet of dieaes to lye upon the houlders of Nature, as being the ole protectree of life. Â¶

Again, I have elewhere hewed, that, even from the firt moment of the conception of an Embrion, there is aigned 2. to every peculiar member one Implantate or Originary Spirit, as immediate preident and Governour thereof, and another Influent Spirit, deradiant from the heart, as the excieator and aitant of the former; which yet is not determined to perfection, nor individually dipoed, unlee firt ubdued to a qualification requiite by the praeparatory power of the Implantate. I have alo taught, in another place, that every member enjoyes the capacity of Vegetation, according to the virtue of its peculiar Ferment originally inoculated into its principles; and that, for this reaon, there can be no expectance of any tranmutation,
conductive to a new generation, unlee by the mediation of that Ferment.

And from hence, by naturall conequence, we may undertand, that all vegetation is made by the pirits; and that o all debility of digetion in the members doth depend upon the diminution of the pirits and their peculiar Ferment, according to that in acred Writ: My pirit (the involucrum or conervatory of the Ferment) hall be attenuated and (therefore) my dayes hortned. So that a member, which in its integrity affords no viible excrement, mut produce a large and contant ource of unnatural humor, when once wounded, injured, diminihed, or impeded in the vigour of its appropriate Ferment. And, finally, it follows from hence, that according to the degrees of the injury and variety of Caues inferring that injury; there mut be generated a difformity and diimilitude of excrements repectively. Â¶

Dieaes, therefore, have their origine, not from one fountain, particularly from the Head (from whence the 3. Schools wildly imagine all Catarrhs to drop down) but from a ingle Idiopathy, or proper indipoition of every part, uperinduced upon the topicall or dometick Ferments. Thus, to example, Wounds, long after their anation, break 4. forth again, and frequently introduce durable lcers, and Apotems: and upon change of Weather, many years after their perfect conolidation, fall into a reincrudecence, and frehly renew their torture. Thus Coughs, Pleuriies, Spittings of blood, and Eriypelous tumors, or inflammations, have their et viciitudes, and, after coniderable intermiions, reinvade. For ome exceive montain Cold, or other Damp uddenly urpriing, the nightly Aer, marih or uliginous Fog, or malignant Fume belched from the acide bowels of Mines, doth frequently, with one aault, o violate and ruine the Ferments of the brain, or Lungs, that from thenceforward, during the whole after-life, they become the too fertil magazines of various excrements. After this manner alo in the eyes, ears, teeth, jaws, &c. Excrements
(not uch as the mucous or limy excretions of the brain) are ordinarily occaioned by the irregularity or diminution of the Ferments peculiar to thoe parts. So Coughs and Athmas, or difficulties of repiration firt begin: and perever by a continued Ferment. Not, in ooth, by reaon of 5. a vicid Phlegme dropping continually from the head; but engendered in the womb of the Lungs, by a violation of their dometick Ferment. For the Lungs more eaily ubmit to the invaion of any forraigne injury, then the other parts of the body: in regard, the Lungs is of all members the firt that grows old, decayed, and dies. As is manifet 6. from the Cough generally infeting old men, and from the rattling in the throats of all dying men, though they perih by any other dieae, and not by affections of the Lungs. For this is proper to the Lungs, in this repect, that they continually uck in crude Aer, and being neer to the heart oppreed, lavihly expend their own trength, and by reaon of that exhaution, decay much the ooner. Â¶

In the firt place I dient from the Schools, becaue I very well know this kind of vitioity in nature to belong to 7. the parts containing, and not to the humors contained. For excrementitious humors of this kind contained, are certain productions, which are begotten by the Archeus, or vitall preident of the particular parts, depraved by ome noxious inquination precedent.

In the econd, I dient from them alo in this point, 8. that I tand aured, that this evill is topicall and primary, and not communicated by Deuteropathy or conent with the head. For the Coughs of old men, which for the plurality dicourage all hopes of retauration, arie from this root; that in the lowet and mallet branches of the Repiratory Artery, or pipe of the Lungs, there doth contantly reide uch a quantity of excrement, generated in the Lungs, which doth not onely obtruct the tubes or conduicts: but alo, by the contagion of its preence, deprave and diminih the Local Ferment; whereupon there is hourly produced a new ource or upply of excrements, as the
plentifull maintainance of Coughs, which in men once entered the calamitous confines of old age, are hardly cured, by remedies known to vulgar heads: in regard uch remedies neither arrive at the part affected, nor, in troth, are they endowed with any retauratory faculty. Thee kinds of excrementitious humors, therefore, are no other but topicall defects of the parts miaffected: and every particular part hath its particular debility, whether innate or acquiite, from a diminution of its vegetative Ferment.
And thus it is evident, that the various treams of excrements 9. flowing from the various parts of the body, are all derived from this one fountain. Â¶

On thee firm grounds I apprehend, firt, That all repetitions of Purgations, in thee affections, are frutraneous and hurtfull: in repect, they levell their power onely againt the productions, or Effects, and not againt the Caues; and chiefly becaue uch vicid excrements, eated remotely from the tomack, are too tubborn and refractory to yield to the laxative operation of Purgers. You may pleas to adde, that although Laxatives may eem to have afforded eae and relief, for a day or two after their ue; inomuch as the mae of crude and inconfected blood in the mezaraick veins being voided by tool, there mut of neceity ucced the more paring dipenation of blood through the body, and penury of nourihment in the Lungs, and by conequence a lee quantity of excrement be rejected: yet do they, by ubtracting from the neceary aliment of the whole, and by leaving behind them an evill tincture in the intruments of common digetion, every day more and more infringe the univerall oeconomy of the body, and impugne the conerving vigour of nature.

This when Phyicians darkly, as through a veile, dicover, 10 and remain ignorant, that they have afforded no benefit to their Patients, by the exhaution of the laudable juces of the body, and the diminution of naturall vigour; they at length remit them to the ober rules of Diet, and kitchen phyick, as the onely hopefull means of their recovery,
and o leave them, by the painfull ue of Fontanels, and reiterated moderate Purges, to run out their remaining ands, medicaly (i. e.) mierably. By which Conceion, firt, they ininuate that wholeome and moderate diet is to be preferred to mot of thoe unfaithfull medicaments of the hops: and upon the tetimony of their own unhappy experience, conclude, that the Patient ought to abtain from them, as hurtfull, and at bet but rarely to be ued. Our wih is, that now, after o many detructive exhautions of ick mens trength, they would it down contented, and in the future no more attempt, by the ame fruitlee means, to dreigne the hopes, bodies, veins, trength, and pures of the ick. At let, I wih, that they would be mindfull of their own Axiome, wherein they unanimouly conent, That the chiefet indication of the cure, is to be deumed from the benefit or harme which things already ued have introduced. Which rule, although it be worthy the bluhes of learned men, and onely fit for the conformity 11. of Empyricks: yet, it may be wihed, that, by the intruction thereof, they would be reclaimed from the practice of their former errors, and no longer in Coughs and Conumptions return to thoe inefficacious remedies, which they have oberved, never to have been beneficiall to any. For then would all Purgatives, Phlebotomy, Errhines, Errhinum et medicamentum, quod naribus inditum, ex cerebro, ine ternutatione, humores & praeertim pituitam evacuat.
Apophlegmatimes, Apophlegmatimi unt remedia, quae in ore aliquandiu detenta, ejuque cavum leniter ferientia, per emiaria palati, capioam pituitam Ã¨ cerebro deducunt; quaeenimpotea frequenti putatione facilÃ¨ excluditur.
Lambatives, drinks of China, Zarza, Saafras, Cauteries in the Coronal uture, and other deceitfull remedies of the ame order, be wholly layed aide, which are brought into ue by Phyicians, that they might not appeare to have received their fees for nothing. It is alo to be wihed, they had uffered themelves to be intructed from their own practice, that while they pointed their endeavours directly againt the Ablation, Revulion, Derivation, and precaution of ecundary Effects, viz. the Excrements wept from the injured Archeus of the particular part: they at the ame time tacitely confeed, that they neither undertood their originals, nor et about the Cure of them, according to the jut method of beginning at the remove
of their primary Caues. And they had farther dicovered, that a medical Coure of Diet, is but a wild, languid, invalid and indeed deperate kind of remedy; and Kitchen Aphorimes too contemptible a militia to encounter o formidable an Adverary, already entered upon the borders of life, and ready to diolve the dicordant Harmony of the whole Compoition, by the generall diffuion of its tyranny. No wonder therefore, if the Common people, oberving the vanity of uch Cures, have taken occaion to create this proverbe, The bet phyick, is to take no phyick. Â¶

More then once have I lamented, out of a deep Commieration 12. of the hard Condition of man, while I read over whole Centuries of the Councels of Phyicians, and chiefly their Commentaries on the 9. Rha. ad Almanorem, where they run over all dieaes of the body, from the Crowne of the head to the ole of the foot; that digging into the Center of each dieae (as they believe and glory) and there exploring the Grandfather, or procatarctick Caue thereof, they ever and anon lay the blame on ome one ingular ditemper, either naturall or acquired: but yet with uch a reerve of uncertainty, that they dare not preciely determine, whether they ought to account that ditemper for the dieae, or onely for the Antecedent Caue of the dieae, about which they Conult. But to prevent mitake, and to be ure of the right, generally in all infirmities they accue both heat and cold. For example, in mot, they cry out upon a Frigidity of the tomack, either olitary, or combined with an exceive Heat of the Liver; whence they foretell Catarrhs to be engendered, and maladies of thoe parts, upon which uch rheumes hall be rained downe: and this hint they purue unto the exploration of the nature not onely of very many Internall, but alo of mot Externall and Cutany defects. And with uch Theorical and Practical decretals do the chools eaon the brains of their Diciples. For thus are infirmities of the eyes, ears jawes, tongue, teeth, chet, arms, loyns, and thighs, charged upon the account of Catarrhs. Thus
have Coughs, Conumtions, difficulties of repiration, Pleuriies, Inflammations of the Lungs, Apoplexies, Palies, uddain Deaths, Impotumes, Spittings of blood, found their pedigrees deduced from Ditillations. Thus finally, is the tomack infeted with Vomiting, Naueounee, dejection of Appetite, and debility of Concoction: as alo the Liver and Spleen become miaffected. For crude and indigetible Phlegme being dropped downe from the retort of the Head, Obtructions, Hardnees, Dropies, Apotems, Schirrous tumors, Fevers, torments of the bowels, &c. are lited under the conduct of Catarrhs.

To which Epidemick tradition of Catarrhs, Paracelus, though otherwie above modety triumphing in his invention 13. of Tartars, and the 3 firt Hypotaticall Principles, Princ pia Hypotatic a unt, quae majori v â¢ ac efficacia prae reliquis pollent; unde in Schola HermeticaCheironia virilia, virtuoa dicuntur, unt

Sulphur, Mercurius, & Sal. Sal et principium hypotaticum, cum vi fermentandi & coagulandi. Ejus ignatura et, ut intrinecus it fuil â¢ , metallorum intar & fixus: ex trinecus autem combutibilis et incinerabilis. Sulphur principium et hypotaticum, cum vi maturandi, tingendi, homogenea attrahendi, heterogenea repellendi, tendendi a centro ad circumferentiam, & viciim. Hujus ignatura et, ut intra it fixum, oleaginoum ive pingue: extra inflammabile ee & fugitivum. Flamma quippe et Sulphur volatile. Mercurius et principium hypotaticum, cum vi vegetativa et intaurativa. Hujus ignatura interna et overe ignem potentem: externa vero et liquidum, glutinoum, incombutibile & frigidum ee. Joh. Raicus tract. de podagra. doth 14. frequently ubcribe, and alwayes openly acknowledge the name of Defluxion (fluen) taggering into elf-contradiction, under the drunken guidance of that great Lady, Incertitude.

And this fabulous cene of Defluxions, which indeed is very well worth our erious tears, do the Schools o polih and trim up, and deliver from hand to hand down to poterity; that it now dares plead precription, and uurpe the acred dignity of truth: yea common Idiots, by their own infirmities made paive Phyicians, tire my ears with a tedious lecture of their Catarrhs. Whereupon, ince it is a taske extremly difficult, and uch as my Genius abhorrs, to root out a cutomary doctrine from the minds of men unacquainted with more rationall wayes of learning, and in the place thereof, implant the eeds of olid truth; chiefly when vulgar heads are of that temper, that, like new veels, they
hardly part with that odour, wherewith they were firt eaoned: it is my cutome, even among perons of honour, to affect ilence, not to preach upon the dieae, or its Caues, everal kinds, and remedies; but quietly concealing my detetation of the eaie theory of the Schools, and diembling an ignorance of all, go away as conenting to whatever hath been aid. Yet, in ome places, I adventure to leave a hint, that I am otherwie intructed, that Fools are not contellated to a capacity of medicinal Principles, nor my elfe to be their Paedagog. At bet, I cannot but admire, that no man hath hitherto, after o long a revolution of time, ever dicovered, and made animadverions on the palpable and uperlative ignorance of Phyicians: but that the grey-haired dreams of the Grecians have drawne the whole Chritian World after them, into a ervitude. To particular; they generally conclude that the head from whence their Nilus of Defluxions doth originally pring, is a Cold Ditemper of the tomack, and an hot ditemper of the Liver: and that the greatet part of mankinde is in ubjection to this tyranny. The manner of its generation they deliver thus; That the tomack, inceantly, during the whole act of Concoction, receiving an accee of immoderate heat from the Liver, mut of neceity, all that while, end up whole clouds of vapours into the braine: and that by reaon the brain is, by its native temperament Cold, and et, like a cover over a boyling pot, or the head of an Alembick, in the highet region of the body; all thoe vapours that acend into it, are againe condened into Water; Which, ince according to the propenity of its nature, it mut tend downwards, doth afford an ample ource to ditillations, and a generall maintainance to mot dieaes. That if this torrent fall down upon the eyes, ears, palate, teeth, &c. thoe parts have very good reaon to bewaile, and with plenty of rheume lament their unkinde detiny, in being o neer neighbours unto, and lying within reach of this tyrant, the Brain: but if upon the Lungs, it is quickly the inevitable 15. occaion of Coughs, Difficulties of repiration, and in fine of Conumtions, of palpitations or tremblings of the heart, and o of
immature death. But if the tream be turned upon the tomack, then doth the tomack uffer the jut punihment of its former ditemper, by admitting debility of Concoction, Crudities, Vomits, Orexies

or inatiate Appetites, Swounings, fainting Pains of the mouth of the tomack, Obtructions, Laskes, durable Fluxes of the belly, violent ejections of Choler upward and downward, fits of the Colick, Atrophies, or univerall leanee from decay of Nutrition, Dropies, Schirrous tumors, and all other defects of the intruments officiall to common Digetion: yea Fevers, Putrefactions of the blood in the veins, as alo tones of the Spleen, Calculi enim quando

Kidneys, and Bladder, have their ordinary materials from the lime of this Defluxion. That if thee rivulets creep into the inmot cloets of the brain, then uddain death, Apoplexies, and Palies immediately enue: but if in the hinder part of the head, by the neck they chanee to wander into the Nerves, Arteries, and Mucles, then mut Gouts, Palies, Pleureies, and Convulions of the receiving parts, unavoidably be introduced: yea all Chirurgicall defects, as Pains, Apotems, and the numerous progeny of lcers, do they father upon Catarrhs.

div.p: For beides thee forementioned ditempers of Heat and Cold, and Defluxions necearily reulting from thence; the Books, Orations, Councels, Converations, Chairs and Practices of Phyicians ound of nothing: and o the whole bulk of the Art of healing, eems, now a dayes, to be moved upon the lender hinges of Purgations, Phlebotomy, Scarifications, Baths, Sweatings, Cauteries, and, in hort, upon no other then the diminutions of trength, and emaciations of the body, or exiccations of Rheumes. 16.

To which end, they impoe upon their Patients, the decoctions of the roots of China, Zarza, and the wood of
Saafras, brought from the Eat-Indies, upon deigne of drying up the luxuriant moyture of the brain: for the mot part meauring the extent of the Pharmaceuticall and Diateticall Theory, by the rule of Heat and Cold.

And by this means, they never releae the ick out of their hands: but perpetually oblige them, like purchaed 17. Bondlaves, to the irkome obervance of their Precepts; though with manifet depair. In regard, while Phyicians remain ignorant of the fundamentals and Caues of the dieae, and by the light of their own unuccesfulnee read the vanity of their Operations, they mut tand convicted of the impoibility of the Sanation: upon this ground, that the naturall Frigidity of the tomack, doth Antipractically, or by Counter violence, impugne the Heat of the Liver; and o thoe remedies which would be beneficiall to the tomack, mut prove offenive and dangerous to the Liver, and o tranpoitively.

All which impotures, ince they conpire to the extirpation of the race of Adam, to the deolation of Commonwealths, 18. and utter oblivion of familyes; I could not but think it my duty (what in me lay) wholly to ubvert and dimantle this execrable hereie of medical Doctrine: and o much the more compulion had I upon my concience to attempt it, in conideration that this Petilence hath poeed the heads of our Europeans, ever ince the dayes of Galen, untill now. Proprio didactro, inquit Helmontius; < in non-Latin alphabet >
enim onat idem, quod minerval latine, five praemium doctrinae. For rich men learn this Doctrine from the cotly dictates of their Pures, and what they have learnt, they oon communicate to others: and thus all dieaes have their tories written in the montrous Romance of Defluxions. Againt which I hall declare, by Poitions granted in the Schools. Â¶
1. The tomack of man, during life, is actually Warme, and its interior membrane or Coate bedewed with a certain 19. moyture.
2. And impoible it is, that any aquous humidity hould be actually eething in the body, and not at the ame time end forth plenty of Vapours from it elf.

3. The uperiour way from the tomack, is the Gullet, or oeophagus, being a membrane round long and hollow, as a Pipe or Cane, extended from the tomack even up unto the jawes, and in ubtance the ame with the interior Coate of the tomack.

4. This Gullet, by the privilege of its native contitution, is ever actually moyt, and contantly (except at times of wallowing) actually hut (otherwie, ditorted in avoydance of a Vacuum, it would laterally fall together, no otherwie then a bladder that wants ome guet to fill its Cavity:) and the ides thereof mutually meet and touch each the other, by the compulion of that neceity of Nature, which forbids a acuity. For the Gullet containg in it, neither meat, drink, nor aer, would of neceity be empty, hould it remain open. But that it is not open, is evident from this, that otherwie, at the wallowing downe of every morell of our Diet the Aer, which would be beneath the morell, and oppoe the decent thereof, were the morell proportionate in gravity to the renitency of the Aer, mut be rammed downe into the cavity of the tomack; and o there mut follow for every morell wallowed a Belch, or redicharge of that aer, by the uperior outlet of the tomack. Finally, ince the membrane of this Gullet is always moyt, the ides thereof would of neceity fall together, if not ditended by ome force: which is never oberved in the diections of dead, nor could be of any ue in living bodies.
5. The mouth of the tomack is hut up by a Natural motion, and not by a Voluntary.

6. And Anatomy affords no other knowledge of the Gullet, more then that it is narrow, lockt up beneath by the Pylorus or inferior orifice of the tomack, and in the neck of man on all ides compreed by very many veels circumjacent.

7. The Gullet neither ucks in, nor containes any Aer: for by reaon of its proper motion, naturall to it as a moyt membrane, and want of any body to ditend it from within, it falls together on all ides.

8. The Gullet is not opened longwayes, but during the decent of Aliment. Which if very dry, makes a tand in the paage, nor eaily decends, unlee driven down by liquor uperadded: which could not be, if the Gullet contained aer beneath the morell, unlee there followed a Belch upon the deglutition of each morell. Yet the top of the Gullet, about the Larinx or head of the wind-pipe, is commonly open.

9. The lower end of the Gullet is contracted by an aliene power, and is therefore never opened but by the violence of ome aliment or other tenent, either entering into, or expuled from the tomack: Or upon the knocking of Hunger, it may be unlocked by a trange key, i. e. not by its own motion, ince the humidity of its ides naturally dipoeth them to Concidence, or falling together.
10. No Aer, and much lee Vapour, arieth out of the tomack, and acends, without giving the loud report of a Belch.

11. Though that heat, which is neceary to the tomack, immediately caueth the exhalation of vapours: yet it follows not, that the ame heat hould protrude thoe vapours upward, with o great violence as is required to break open the dore of the tomack, being fat lockt, and ditend the Gullet, ince any one of thee contradictory Thees being conceded, it will be a genuine inference, that every man mut be troubled with continuall belchings.

12. In the tomack, as in all other veels moderately hot, every watery vapour doth ooner, upon the let compreion, return to its primitive conitence, and unite again in drops; then to be of power ufficient to elevate and ditend a cloely compreed membrane of coniderable magnitude. Where we oberve, by the by, That Vapours are not the Caue of Belchings: but onely the Gas ilvetre, Gas bifurcatum, ab Helmontio notro fabricatum inveni: primum cilicet Aquae, ive Meteoron; ecundum ylvetre. Ga. Meteoron deignat Aquam, in vaporem, per geniale aeris frigus (ubi omnia eo emel deducta conumuntur, & in pritinum aquae elementum retrocedunt) reolutam. Quinam vapor alterius utique ortis et, quÃ m vapor per Calorem ucitatus: eo itaque repectu, paradoxi licentia, in nominis magÃ¨ convenientis egetate, halitum illum Gas nominavit Author, non longe Ã¢ Chao veterum ecretum. Gas autem ylvetre, et piritus quidam naturae hominis planÃ¨ hotilis, atque Ã¡ prunoribus nondum cognitus; qui nee vai â¢ cogi, nec in corpus viibile reduci, nii extincto prius emine, potet. Corpora enim continent hunc piritum, & quandoque tota in ejumodi forum halitum abcedunt: non quidem quod actu init ipis (iquidem detineri non poet, imÃ² totum concretum avolaret) ed et piritus concretus, & more corporis coagulatus, excitaturque acquiito Fermento, ut in vino fermentante, omphacio, pane, hydromellite, itemque ruber ille ex Chryulca operante eructatus: vel additamento peregrino, ut ex auro, adjecto ale Armeniaco: vel tandem per aliquam Dipoitionem Alterativam, qualis et Aatio, repectu pomi. 13. That granting a Natural pirit of the yet imperfect blood in the Liver, all the veins, by reaon of their contant heat, would either about the parts of the Liver, or in their capillary branches, generate Catarrhs, which the Schools have baulked in their hunting of dieaes. Â¶

div.head: The Concluions erected on the premied Conceions. Â¶
div.p: FRom thee Poitions, confeed by generall Conent, and demontrated by the ocular evidence of Anatomy, it naturally follows, in the firt place
1. That no vapour can acend from the tomack to the head; and the materiall Caue of Catarrhs, vulgarly believed, mut faile, and the very groundwork of the doctrine of Defluxions be demolihed.

2. If o great a mit of ignorance hath urrounded the world in things manifet and obvious to the obervation of ene: what Cimmerian blindnee may not be upected, in the common theory of uch things as lye more deep and abtrue, and therefore have their Caualites onely dicernable by the opticks of the mot acute Reaon?

3. That ubmitting our beliefe to the doctrine of the Schools, a healthy and hot tomack would generate more and greater howers of Catarrhs, then an unhealthy, weak and cold one; which is point blanck contratry to the opinion commonly embraced.
4. That, in order to the Cure of Defluxions, according to the conequence of their theory, we ought to endeavour the Refrigeration, rather then the Calefaction of the tomack.
5. That all men would of neceity be equaly obnoxious to Catarrhs, and o continually infirme.
6. Upon this ground, that all men have their Gullet, Brain, and Stomack actually hot, equaly moyt, and contituted in the ame Figure.
7. That every man would naturally, like wine, belch at every tep he treads: ince the indeinent heat and moyture mut unavoydably tranmit continuall Clouds of vapours from the tomack.

8. That although we hould decend to allow, that a vapour exhaled from the tomack might be of force ufficient
to ditend the Gullet; yea and be evaporated without ructation: yet would it remain of exceeding difficulty to infer an apprehenion, that this vapour would not ooner be dicharged by the annexed and open tubes of the mouth and notrils, then make a long and difficult progree up to the brain, by the narrow Meanders and blockt up avenews of a membrane. That this Vapour, teaming up from the furnace of the tomack, would necearily carry along with it a fulome Hautgout of the meat then uffering the act of Concoction, by the variety of ungratefull odours acquaint the noe with the unavoury tory of its various mutations, and be horridly offenive both to our elves and company: and thus if all thoe frequent belches were thus trongly perfumed by Corruption, our very breath alo, continually blated with them, would ave us the trouble of forreigne poyons, diparage the fatall emilions of the Bailick, and be as dangerous to Converation, as the fumes of the Lago di Tripergola Avernus, Gr. < in non-Latin alphabet > , quo nullae aves accedunt, ob tetrum ejus odorem: propter quam graveolentiam, etiam hÃ®c decenus ad inferos olim ee credebatur. Gas ylvetre. in Campania, or the ulphureous farts of our Grandmother, when delivered from the Colick, by the Criis of an Earthquake.

9. That ince the Materiall caue of belching is a nimble Wild pirit, ariing for our Aliment, and far more ubtil then a vapour; but yet doth never invade the Brain, unlee, upon hutting the mouth, it chance to advance to the forepart of the head, through the funnell of the palat, and be thence exploded by the notrils: auredly, much lee can vapours, that are more groe and corporeal, acend o high as to ininuate themelves into all the narrow creeks and intricate Cells of the brain.

10. That thee volatile and fugitive pirits, the cauers of ructation, are never carried in a direct path, up to the region of the brain; but in an oblique, leading through the organ of melling: and therefore they never afford an odour, or become ubject to the perception of the odoratory nerves, but when the mouth is hut, at the intant of their eruption; much lee can a vapour from the tomack, by its own pontaneous motion, arrive at the remotet cloets of the brain.

11. That though we condicend, that Vapours, the material caue of Catarrhs, may in ome degree arie up to the head, at leat to the organ of melling: yet can we not conceive, that this can happen, but when the mouth is hut; and o whoever gapeth, can never be infected with Defluxions, and by inference, to keep the mouth open, at the time of ructation, is a mot eaie and infallible precaution of the generation of rheums.

12. That ince two bodies cannot o far rebell againt the conerving Laws of Nature, as mutually to penetrate each the others dimenions, in one and the ame place; and ince the paage from the jawes up into the brain is exceeding narrow, oppleted (for there is no vacuity in thoe organs) barrocadoed above and o impervious (for our very breath, though violently compreed by topping of the mouth and notrils, cannot force open a way into the catle of the brain:) therefore cannot a vapour, ariing from the tomack, approach the bais of the brain. By example, a Cane or hollow Tube, that is cloely luted in the upper orifice, held in an erect poition over a team of hot vapours, doth not admit them to acend through its perforation, by reaon of the Aer, wherewith it was before poeed.

13. Granting, that a vapour may clime upwards; yet would it not meet with any Plane or Concave, upon which it might, by Condenation, be reunited into drops: and much lee any part of uch figure, which reembleth the head of an Alembick, or Pot-lid. But in the bais of the brain, whether we gratis allow a vapour to acend, is a narrow place, called the Pelvis, or brain tunnell; which endeth two mall tubes, or outlets, toward the notrils, and as many backward toward the neck. Good Jeu! when wilt thou be pleaed to cat this devil out of the Schools? when will the meaure of thee fatall evils be full, and the Vintage of thee oure Grapes come; that, at length, by the comfortable unhine of thy truth, this Aegyptian night may be exhaled, and this mit of horrid calamities that its heavy on the heads of all the wretched onnes of Adam, be dipelled? Thy anwer is, there can be no remedy for his blindnee, who wilfully and tubbornly huts his eyes againt the light of a confeed verity. Therefore,

Thou unmov'd Rule of Truth, and Font of Love!

54. Some Anatomits there are who have diected a living Dog; and when they came to the Larynx, drenched him with milke, or other broth, tinged with Saffron or Bole Armeniack, to the end they might perceive whether any part of the liquor entered the lungs: and found that a very mall quantity thereof gave a tincture to the ides of the Apera Arteria. On this they cried out, that there mut be an inenible and ordinary decent of excrements from the brain into the Lungs; and enacted for an etabliht truth, that Lambatives, ince they are carried immediately into the Larynx, and thence lide down into all the mot lender and remote tubes of the Apera Arteria, mut be the ole and extreme remedy of Conumtions, and the mot prevalent means to Conolidate lcers in the Lungs. For, Firt, what can they expect that Syrups and Lambatives hould doe, in the lender branches or divarications of the Apera Arteria, more then inevitably introduce the michiefe of obtructions? To what end, therefore, hould thee fulome Loochs naturally and ordinarily affect that way of decent into the lungs, or be tranmitted thither, or there entertained? ince in that place they can neither be digeted, nor changed into good and nutritive or balamicall juyce; nor yet conduce to the cure of either the purulent effluxions from ulcers, or vicid Muccus expectorated. And further, if ome part of our liquor hould ordinarily drop into the lungs, then would the ordinary pitle of healthy men avour of the broths eaten, or yrups lickt down. And although our firt pitle ometimes relih of the yrups, or other liquid remedies, newly wallowed down; yet uch arieth not from the Lungs, but Palate and other parts eated in vicinity to the jawes: nor doe the ucceeding alivous rejections, for that reaon, confee an inquination or tincture of uch Lambatives, as in another cae the ucceeding pitle returns fuliginous exhalations or fumes, received into the Lungs, a good while after their firt admiion. Again, were this feazible, then would any man, who hould lick up everall ounces of Syrup, in one evening, be, ere many minuts, reduced to the boome of his cold grandmother, by the inevitable detruction not onely of an Athma, but even of uffocation enuing; for a part of thoe Syrups mut fill up and choak the great pipe or cavity of the rough arterie. Seriouly, our wonder may be excued, if we tand amazed,
how the Schools, educed by o blew and dull an experiment of a Dogge, have baulked the obervation, that this coloured broth, or Milk died with Saffron, was rapt down in the Larynx, not by the ordinary way of Deglutition; but unawares and preposterouly, the poore ditracted animal howling amids his torments, and o opening the Epiglottis. Not that the ame is done of cutome in healthy, or frequently oberved in rheumatick perons. For preciely, if a man in an extreme fit of the tone, endeavouring to make water, doth chance unwittingly to open the porthole of his are, and confront an Irih man; mut it therefore be the proper function of the Sphincter of the bladder, when it relaxeth it elfe, and gives way to the efflux of the urine, ordinarily alo to unlock the phincter of the port Aequiline? For tis no rarity, for parts of the body, when their oeconomie is infringed and diturbed into tumult and confuion, by exceive pain and torture, to perform their functions depravedly; and draw other parts alo, to which they are allied by vicinity of ituation, or connexion, into the ame diorder and irregularity. If therefore Suffumigations and aromatick exhalations, uch as promie a gratefull uccour to the Lungs in their oppreions, be injurious and burdenome; what will not groer and limy Lambatives do, though we grant them to arrive at the lower veels of the lungs, with all their vertue and efficacy about them? No man, that ever aw but one diection, will deny, that when ever any thing is wallowed down into the tomack, at the ame intant the Larynx is hut cloe by the Epiglottis, or trap doore, that carries the figure of an Ivy-leafe; o that not the mallet atome can lip into the Lungs. And I have known ome men trangled, who had their Epiglottis not hut ufficiently cloe but on one ide, by reaon of a Convulion of one part, and a reolution or Palie of the other. Â¶

55. And here we are falne upon the detection of another collateral Error of the Schools; in particular, their unadvied Aertion, that Lambatives wallowed down gently and by degrees, the head being at the ame time reflected into a poition looking above the horizon, decend into the Lungs; but not thoe, that are wallowed down greedily, and at once. If o, I demand,
whether the dog under the diecting knife, did lick and by degrees wallow downe the coloured liquor; or chop it down at once? To what purpoe did the Anatomits poure it into his throat to be drank at one wallow or gulp, if they knew before hand, that it could not fall into the Lungs, unlee lickt down gently? But letting this Hypotheis tand, that the Lungs abolutely abhor the admiion of all external things, meer Aer and uch as is not incorporated to Fumes and Exhalations onely excepted: and then it will necearily follow, that whether any thing be lickt down gently, or drank down ravenouly at once; yet till the Preident of the Epiglottis, or janitor of the Lungs attends the execution of his function, and oberves the Clauure of the Larynx; ince thereupon depends no lee then the hazard of life. This, I conceive, may make it indubious to the mot prejudicate, that Lambatives and yrups, though they may, by introducing an unctuous urface upon the parts, make them more mooth, lippery, and o more fit for the rejection of vicid excrements flowing from the palate and other parts adjacent; yet are they of no mall detriment to the tomack, nor can, in the let degree, or larget latitude of intention, afford eae or benefit in affections of the Lungs. But the Schools reply, that the alivous rheume or defluxion, doth inenibly, and by its own pontaneous laps, or natural tendency, ditill into the Larynx; and that, in this relation, Lambatives mut be beneficial and anative.

56. But neither of thee articles can tand; ince into what poition oever the neck be dipoed, or however inflected, yet the ame care and warinee of Nature to praevent that nothing drop or ininuate into the Lungs, is contantly continued. I beheld a Tumbler, not long ince, tand upon his head, his hands and feet inverted, and in that poture drink a glae of wine. I appeal to Anatomy, and willingly ubmit my hand to the ferula.

57. Many there are, out of whoe mouthes, while they leep, run whole torrents of pitle; who if they chance to leep in a upine poture, that is on their backs, it intantly
happens, that they mut turn themelves on one ide, or awake and it up, nature being affrighted by the terror of the danger imminent: and if any of the pitle fall accidentally and unawares into the Larynx; thenceforward, untill all be again exploded, they cough unceantly. But, to come home to the center of the buinee; what comfort or uccour can ugar, mixt with the cadaverous Lungs of a Fox, or imbued with the juice of Coltsfoot, adfer to the Lungs; when they utterly abhor the intruion of any forreigner, admit nothing but Aer unlee by accident and ex improvio, and when any thing is entred into their confines, immediately reject it with great anxiety and labour? Can uch a remedy uffice to the retauration of the decayed Faculties? Can this cut up Catarrhs by the root, or expunge the eminal miame, or original impreion fixt upon the Archeus? I profee, on which hand oever I turn me, on what part oever I place my diquiitions, I cannot dicover, that the Schools war againt dieaes, with any other weapons, but the wilde dreams of the Gentiles, or trike at any thing beyond their effects and econdary Productions, leaving the head and principal Caualities unaaulted; and all this, by reaon of their ignorance of the Eence and Caues of Dieaes. And hence hath the name of Phyician falne under the facete reprehenion of Comedians, and this proverbial reproach, that Phyicians care not what they hould think, what do, or how order their meditations, in order to their obedience unto that trict Precept: Be ye merciful, as your Father which is in heaven, is merciful, grown into ue. And, as St. Bernard, concerning the Clergy feeding upon the ins of the people, in repect they live upon no other revenews, but Almes; o I concerning Phyicians. For they conider not, whether they dicharge their duty to the Commandment, or atisfie the debt of Charity; who banquet and grow fat upon the defections, languors, and infirmities of the people. Often have I pondered, but dicover I cannot, how thee Plagues of Aegypt, thee clouds of palpable darknee, were introduced upon the Schools; unlee from hence, that being
eaoned with evil principles, and infected with unjutifiable traditions, they frequently met with Affections, which, according to their outward appearance, and without cruple or tricter indagation, they intantly referred to the fabulous cene of Catarrhs.

58. For intance, a certain ick peron, invaded with a head ach, oon after feels a dull and ponderous pain in the neck, a difficulty and indipoition to motion; and the leaden plummets of Morpheus are too light to draw down the curtains of his eyes; on the neck of thee Accidents enues a manifet pain and imbecillity of the loyns, which eems to be traduced down to the thighs, and thence to make a progree to the legs and feet. Hereupon it is decreed, that Pain (ince an Accident of inhaerence) cannot tranmigrate from one ubject to another; unlee omething Material, ucceively trickling down from the brain along the mucles of the pine, and by a pontaneous motion ariing from its own tendency to declivity, remove from a uperior to an inferior part: which may very accommodately make out the received Appellation of a Catarrh. It mut become our method of exploring verity, to examine and detect the dotage and improbability of this perwaion concerning defluxions, by the judicial tet of Anatomy.

59. For if this dolorifick matter ditill, by ucceive drops, from the brain by the neck; no man can doubt, but that it mut be tranported thither, either through the Ventricles of the brain, or through the ubtance and membranes of the brain, or betwixt the Pia and Dura mater, or betwixt the Dura mater and the Skull, or, in fine, betwixt the Skull and the Skin. For the Conequence is warrantable from a ufficient enumeration of the parts. But, firt, not through the Ventricles of the brain; ince that could not come to pae without the inevitable introduction of an Apoplexy, or univeral Palie: if the doctrine of the Schools, concerning the origination of thee dieaes, tand firme. For if the matter of the Defluxion be excluded from the cavities in the fore part of the brain, and thence dicharged upon the
fourth ventricle, and o carried into the pinal marrow ucceively; it cannot but horridly offend thoe noble parts, and being an alien and acrimonious excrement, caue deperate and invincible obtructions, and by conequence an Apoplexy or Palie. Secondly, the matter of this Defluxion cannot, per
< in non-Latin alphabet > , by tranudation through the ubtance of the brain, be firt accumulated between the brain and its thinner invetment, the Pia mater, and thence delaps; o that both Coats may yet keep their continual ditance and eparation from the very marrow of the pine: in regard the defluxion in its decent cannot but commit a divulion and olution of unity, in the medullary roots of the nerves, according to their longitude; (i. e.) as they run out in their ditinct dieminations. Which wanteth not a multitude of aburdities. In like manner, hould the Catarrh be rained down betwixt the two membranes; each of thoe lender invetments, provided by nature to envellop the pinal marrow, would be double: which Anatomical inpection could never yet jutifie. And hould we allow it o to be, it would not onely impede the motion of the Mucles; but alo excite extreme torture, and convulive retractions of the Nerves. So there lieth an Error in the Theis; ince the Nerve, indeed, is the organ delative of the mandates of the Will, (i. e.) the mediatory intrument by which the Will tranmits her piritual Mercuries on an errand to the mucles: but not Executive of Voluntary motion, (i. e.) not the immediate executioner of the commands given out. More plainly thus; the Will is Queen Regent; the Animal pirits, the Nuncij, or Embaadors; the Nerve, the intrument of their tranvection or delation from the brain, or white-hall of the oul, to the member to be imployed; and the mucle, the executioner of her deignes. That a Nerve is not the executioner of Voluntary motion, may be clearly argued from hence; that very few nerves, in thicknee exceeed a thread of double twited ilk. Now a Nerve, being inerted into the external part of its peculiar mucle, cannot probably convey the rheume down to the midle of the mucle, without inferring
a Palie of that part, from its own obtruction, or a convulion from the aerimony and virulency of the Defluxion. Again, if they hall affirme, that the Catarrh doth trickle down betwixt the Dura mater and the Skull; I may appeal for deciion to Anatomy, which autoptically demontrateth, that the perforations of the pondils of the pine, through which the nerves are threaded in their elongations from their original, the pinal marrow, are o exactly fitted to their magnitude, that not a hair can be thrut between, without a enible Compreion of the nerve; o that, by conequence, there can be no void pace left for the intruion of a Catarrh into the mucles, from the pinal marrow. We add, that though our Adveraries could find out a place; wherein this fictitious rheume may be congregated; or paage for its defluxion upon the pinal marrow, and diffuion thence through the perforatiens of the pondils into the mucles: yet, we believe, it would amue their ophitry, to give a plauible reaon of the ucceeding progree thereof, and fully to make out, how a humor, once delaped upon a nerve running out betwixt two pondils, can remigrate, or return back again to invade other nerves ucceively one after the other. What, doth the wanton rheume grow weary of one nerve, and to atisfie its deire of change, at pleaure remove to another? Tis a Quaere not unworthy a ubtantial determination, how a deluge of alt rheume can tream along a tender and extremly enible nerve, without cauing a tuper, or dull inenibility, in that member into which it is inerted? Can it ininuate into the tendinous head, and thence creep along into the taile of a mucle? Can it retreat thence again, to aault other mucles ucceively, as the ituation of the econd is more prone or declive then of the former, and that then the third, &c? or, if there may be a new upply of the defluxion, contantly ucceeding, imagined to flow from parts above, to freh ones below; how comes it to pae, that the uperior parts, firt invaded, obtain an immunity from the michiefe? For ince the rivulet of rheume doth pring from one fountain, the brain; and run in one
continued Chanel, the pinal marrow: why hould it not rather follow the old tract, then wander into a new, and undergo the difficulties of forcing, and as it were mining out a freh current? Why doth it, as if carried on by an adulterous uncontancy, deert its antiently accutomed bed; and affect the embraces of a freh, nay frequently a feeble part? Why doth it forake its frequented quarters, and range in quet of trang and never yet frequented lodgings? Hath it uch an Appetite or malitious propenity inherent, that goads it on to variety of objects, whereon to ate its hotility? For concluion; that this Error can expect no anctuary, in the poibility of the rheums defluxions between the skull and the skin, and through the firme ubtance of the Mucles, each being inveted with a tunicle ufficiently compact and thick: may be amply collected from our precedent diquiitions. 60. All this being ummd up, by the impartial Arithmetick of Reaon, and examined by mature judgement; the total Product mut amount to this: that there can be no way, medium, connexion, or dependence, by which a Catarrh may ubit, in verity. And ince no rheume or material principle can be found out to have decended, even in any of thoe dieaes, for whoe ake chiefly the Schools firt invented this Chimera of Catarrhs: Know all the friends of truth, that as often as any peregrine Aer or blat, any offenive odor, any putrefactive Ferment, or exotick Seminality is impreed upon, or conceived in the Influent pirit; o often is that contaminate and degenerate pirit excommunicated from the participation of Vitality by the evere jutice of the incened Archeus. And the Genius or dipoition of this depraved Seminality conceived, is of no lee power then this, that it can tranmit the Influent pirit, made an alien to its primitive purity by the aumption of an exotick Ferment, rather to parts eated at ditance and in the uburbs, then uch as are neighbours to the Bialto or palace of life. 61. By this time, we believe, it is plain and unquetionable, that no alt, acid, harp, phlegmatick, or Cholerick humor can ditil from the brain; but that, whenever the Influent pirit, polluted with ome alien and putrefactive impreion, doth arrive at any part of the body; then doth nature, without delay, end thither the Latex, or oure of erous humidity, to expung this impreion, or at leat rine away the Excrements, there growing from the depravation of the digetive Faculty. For the Spirit, once vitiated by any forreigne Contagion, wildly rangeth at pleaure through the nerves, arteries, yea and the very habit of the body; whereupon, the ick eeming to feel as it were the defluxion, or trickling down of a cold rheume, the brain is immediately accued as treacherous, and the grand author of this ryot and irregularity in nature. Now ince the Latex is ent to the part newly invaded by this malignant impreion, not as the primitive Caue of the evill (though frequently, by accident, it doth foment and aggravate the michief, and o make the vitioity more durable) but as a relief, or tream to wah away the impreion: hereupon have the Schools, to this day, remained doubtful, and durt never go o far as poitively to determine; whether in the Gout the Catarrb is derived from the head, by the Nerves: or whether tranmitted from the Liver onely, by the Veins. And thus evident it is, that the Phlegme and Choler of the Schools flow not from one fountain, or Cataract; as though the brain were the Common ewer of all thee impurities. Again, as for the lat refuge, whereunto the Schools flye, for protection of their impoible dream of Catarrhs; namely the Declivity or downwardnee of the ituation of the members, as in relation to the brain, and the facility of the paages: it may eaily appear to be too rotten and fragile to afford them helter. Since as in dead bodies there are none of thee repective ituations, but onely in living; o alo all motion of humors in the body is immediately caued by the Influent pirit, as the onely impetum faciens, and mediately derived from the Principle of vitality in whoe occonomy
the Acent of humors is of no more difficulty then the decent. For in living bodies, no humor oweth its motion downward, to the declive tendency of its Gravity: but, in impartial truth, to the aim or direction of that miive power, which levelled it at this or that determinate part. Hitherto concerning the impreion of an External depravity upon the Influent pirit: it follows that we declare the probability and manner how the ame pirit may conceive, and as it were batch an internal Character, or dometick tincture of corruption. After this the uncivil Latex, like a rude ouldier that intrudes himelfe into quarters againt the will of the Landlord, forceth itelf into the ociety of the offended Influent pirit; and though unfit for its converation, as well in regard of its Acidity, as immoderate quantity, yet it till followeth and hangs upon its skirts.
